title: Republicans 'absolutely delighted' over Jasmine Crocket's Senate run
description: US Speaker of the House Mike Johnson has revelled in Texas Representative Jasmine Crockett’s announcement that she is running for a Senate seat.  The House speaker hilariously rubbed his hands together, saying he was “absolutely delighted” to hear the announcement.  Johnson counited saying Crockett’s run for the Senate is one of “the best things to happen to Republicans in a long time”.  The House speaker finished by calling Crockett one of the faces of the Democratic party, wishing her to have the “largest, loudest microphone” she can get.  The Democratic Representative made her announcement at a rally where she vowed to fight Trump.

title: Albanese promotes ‘world leading’ social media reforms as countries follow suit
description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese discusses the international response to Australia’s recent under-16s social media ban.  “This is world-leading, yesterday I did interviews with Japanese TV, with CNN, with BBC and with other international platforms,” Mr Albanese said.   “They are all looking at this; world leaders have been in contact as well.”

title: ‘Time to modernise’: Prince William to scrap ‘weird’ royal Christmas traditions
description: UK barrister and broadcaster Andrew Eborn reacts to Prince William making a major change to some of the Royal Family’s Christmas traditions.  “One of the things he said with this great interview … is we’ve got to modernise the Royal Family, we’re going to get rid of a lot of the pomp,” Mr Eborn told Sky News Digital Presenter Gabriella Power.  “A bit of a pity really, because I think people like the pomp, but he’s ready, he thinks some of the Sandringham rules are really, really weird.”

title: ‘A Princess for the people’: Catherine hailed as ‘glorious’ after carol service
description: UK barrister and broadcaster Andrew Eborn praises Princess Catherine as “glorious” after she hosted her annual carol concert alongside stars and charity heroes.  “We go from the absurdity of the Montecito Madness to the glorious Princess Catherine,” Mr Eborn told Sky News Digital Presenter Gabriella Power.  “It was a glow up, wasn’t it? Pure class.  “It was at Westminster Abbey, they had William, George, Charlotte, Louis, they were all there.  “It was great to see her again after her own cancer diagnosis, and people love Princess Catherine … she’s a Princess for the people.”

title: ‘Absolute scandal’: Meghan’s chocolate bars trigger outrage over eye-watering price
description: UK barrister and broadcaster Andrew Eborn blasts Meghan Markle’s new chocolate bars as “an absolute joke” amid growing backlash over their price.  “It is an absolute scandal … and it’s 12 American dollars, not even Australian dollars,” Mr Eborn told Sky News Digital Presenter Gabriella Power.  “Apparently, they sold out in hours; it’s probably only two bars available.  “Reviewers basically said it’s an absolute joke for 12 pounds for a chocolate bar with weird flavours in it.”

title: ​ Concerns over China-made ‘flat-pack IKEA-style’ homes in Melbourne
description: Sky News contributor Jaimee Rogers is concerned with the “amount of jobs” Australia is sending “over to China” as it’s been revealed China-made homes are being assembled in Melbourne.  “This should be sending chills down the spine of everyone that works in the construction industry,” Ms Rogers told Sky News host Peta Credlin.  “They will be 85 per cent built over in China … but it will always have that query as to whether or not we can ensure that top quality of construction.  “Having a flat-pack IKEA-style home really doesn't tickle my fancy.”

title: ‘The rules have been set’: Albanese dodges questions on changing MP spending rules
description: Prime Minister Anthony Albaense refuses to answer whether he believes MP spending rules should be changed.   “The rules have been set, the rules have been set by the former government,” Mr Albanese said.  “What I’m focused on today is an issue which is a revolution.”

title: Greens Senator ducks Sky News interview after taxpayer foots bill for lobbyist husband’s flights
description: Greens Senator Sarah Hanson-Young was a no show for her regular Thursday morning panel appearance on Sky News Australia’s First Edition program.  The Greens Senator normally appears with Deputy Nationals Leader Kevin Hogan to discuss political issues facing the country.  This comes amid Ms Hanson-Young facing scrutiny over her use of taxpayer money to transport her husband to and from Canberra.

title: Trump ‘determined’ to get rid of Maduro as US seizes Venezuelan oil tanker
description: The Australian’s Foreign Editor Greg Sheridan reacts to the escalation between Venezuela and the US.  “It seems that Trump is determined that Maduro must get out of Venezuela,” Mr Sheridan told Sky News Australia.  “There are grounds to be concerned about the hyper militarisation of Trump’s relations with Latin America.”

title: ‘She genuinely cares’: Melania praised for ‘kindness’ while reading Christmas book to sick kids
description: Broadcaster Dee Dee Dunleavy applauds US First Lady Melania Trump for letting “really nasty” online attacks “flow over her”.  This comes after the first lady faced flak for not showing kids pictures of a book she was reading them in a hospital.  “She was doing something really sweet and kind, she was upholding a long-standing tradition which is to go and read to the children at that hospital at Christmas time,” Ms Dunleavy told Sky News host Rita Panahi.    “I don’t imagine the children were upset at all.  “She genuinely cares about children.”

title: ‘I don’t understand’: Albanese can’t define ‘success’ after recent social media ban
description: Shadow Communications Minister Melissa McIntosh criticises the government for not defining measures of success for the under-16 social media ban.  “I am astonished that the Prime Minister today could not say what success was,” Ms McIntosh told Sky News host Chris Kenny.  “The minister herself not being able to say what success is.  “I really don’t understand that.”

title: Trump forces tourists to provide their social media activity to enter the US
description: Tourism and Transport Chief Executive Margy Osmond discusses US President Donald Trump’s plans to make tourists hand over social media data to enter the US.  “You’ll have to expose something like five years of your social media activity,” Ms Osmond told Sky News Australia.  “It’s unclear at the moment whether that’s public and private or just public.”

title: ​ ‘Drop’ in tourism as Australians travelling to the US must hand over their social media
description: Tourism and Transport Chief Executive Margy Osmond says approvals to travel to the US could take a “lot longer” as authorities will do “additional checking” of social media under the Trump administration.  “They have now applied a visa integrity fee, which is $250, to a whole range of countries,” Ms Osmond told Sky News Australia.  “We might see a bit of a drop, by the middle of 2026, in terms of those Australians travelling to the US.”

title: BBC engulfed in a new controversy after admitting it ‘misled viewers’ with another Trump ‘lie’
description: Sky News host Rita Panahi reacts to the latest scandal to engulf the UK’s national broadcaster, the BBC.  “More bad news for the BBC with the British public broadcaster admitting it misled viewers by claiming that Donald Trump called for Liz Cheney to be shot in the face,” she said.  “In the days before the presidential election last year, a presenter on the BBC said that Donald Trump ‘appeared to suggest Liz Cheney should face a firing squad for her stance on foreign policy’.  “In an internal memo, BBC News said its coverage had been inaccurate, but no correction was ever issued publicly.  “Of course, he did no such thing. Donald Trump was merely making the point that people who are pro-war, like Liz Cheney, are rather cavalier about risking other people’s lives, but they would never put themselves in the firing line.”

title: Meghan reportedly plans on sending ill father a letter after he ‘begged’ to see her
description: Sky News host Rita Panahi reports on Meghan Markle’s father “begging” to see his daughter while he lies in hospital.   “Meghan Markle is planning to reach out to her estranged dad, Thomas, a second time following his near-death experience,” Ms Panahi said.  “She was hoping to get a letter to him as soon as she identified the hospital where he is recovering.  “A source … has told Page Six that she had been calling local hospitals to try to locate her father so that this letter could be delivered to him.  “He has been crying out to have some contact.”
